newsitem.title: USA: PG&E Energy Trading CEO targets N.American market.
newsitem.headline: PG&E Energy Trading CEO targets N.American market.

text.p: Lyn Maddox, the newly-appointed head of PG&E Energy Trading, said he is fixing his sights on all of North America in a bid to make PG&E one of the biggest energy wholesalers in the U.S.
"We are already very close to being in the top three, and hope to be there by the end of the year," Maddox said Thursday in a telephone interview with Reuters.
Maddox will take up his post as president and chief executive officer of the new unit from May 12, heading San Francisco-based PG&E Corp's competitive wholesale commodity trading and marketing unit.
He comes to PG&E from PennUnion Energy Services in Houston, a leading energy commodity marketing company.
Maddox said PG&E Energy Trading plans to set up a single trading operation in Houston with about 160 employees, including risk managemanent and support staff.
"Our primary focus is going to be outside California, frankly. This is primarily a continental, North American play to develop new markets," he said.
"We think we have all the ingredients to compete with the likes of an Enron or Southern," he said, citing other key competitors in the opening gas and electricity marketplace.

PG&E Energy Trading is a central element in PG&E Corp's bid to break out of its traditional service territory in northern California and move into the nation's $200 retail electricity industry as it moves toward open competition.

The Houston-based subsidiary will coordinate all of PG&E's energy trading activities, including those formerly conducted by Energy Source Inc (ESI), Teco Pipeline in Texas, and PG&E Energy Services Inc.
PG&E acquired ESI, a Houston-based gas marketer, in December, 1996.
It will also include Valero Energy Corp's trading activities, pending approval of PG&E and Valero's merger plan.
"Hopefully, closure of the Valero merger will occur sometime in July. This will give us a lot of flexibility in Texas," Maddox said.

The merger, valued at $1.5 billion, still needs final approval from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in Washington and from Valero shareholders, a move Maddox expects at Valero's next shareholder meeting in June.
Valero Natural Gas operates a 7,500-mile pipeline system that can carry about three billion cubic feet of gas a day.

Maddox said he expects Valero to give the new trading unit a "very strong" presence in the Midwest, while ESI will boost the company's profile in the East, a region he admitted needs a lot of business development.
Part of PG&E Energy Trading's strategy involves building a North American network of natural gas transmission and storage hubs to give its traders a valuable operational cushion.
"We need to create hubs...We are looking forward to working with Valero on this," he said.
Maddox said he envisions developing a continental network of seven hubs, located on the U.S. Gulf Coast, in Texas, west Texas, the Northeast, Northwest, Chicago area, and Calgary.
The company will continue its activities in Canada through PG&E Energy Trading, Canada, in Calgary, which recently changed its name from PG&E Energy Source of Canada.
PG&E Energy Trading will start off with natural gas sales estimated at 4.5 billion cubic feet a day.
Maddox said he did not yet have an estimate for the group's initial power sales.
He also said there would be no need to borrow to fund the new unit, since each of the group's components already are financially self-sustaining.
Provided the Valero merger goes ahead as planned, Maddox estimated the new unit would be able to make its first revenue contributions to PG&E Corp sometime in the third quarter.
"But this will be better reflected in the fourth quarter," he said.
((--New York Power Desk 212 859 1621))
